entry.title: Newsletter #99
entry.content:
It’s TechThursday again!

And here we are with what we read this week! Enjoy!

  • 12 Little-Known CSS Facts (The Sequel)

  • A framework for creating responsive UI’s for mobile and web using Markdown Syntax

  • A large data set of historic human events

  • A proxy written in Go with Http middlewares like stream, forward, roundrobin, rate limiting etc..

  • AntiPatterns

  • Ceramic is a library for creating desktop applications with web technologies and Common Lisp

  • CloudBoost | Database as a Service for the next web

  • ClusterSSH for your iTerm

  • Codeception – BDD-style PHP testing.

  • Cool Retro Terminal with QT for OSX and Linux

  • Create your own framework on top of the Symfony Components

  • Defining a High Performance Team: It’s not just about Structure

  • Docker Swarm and experimental multihost networking with docker-machine and boot2docker

  • Docker and Configuration Management

  • Docker’s Testing Infrastructure

  • Docker: The “latest” Confusion

  • Fast, Zero-Downtime Deploy with Serf and Lox

  • Fired

  • How Docker has made life awesome for SOASTA DevOps | SOASTA

  • How to Merge Two Docker Images

  • How to Speed Up Lo-Dash ×100? Introducing Lazy Evaluation.

  • I’m Sorry, But Agile Won’t Fix Your Products

  • The web is fast by default, let’s keep it fast

  • Introducing Incremental DOM

  • Just Don’t Hire 0x Engineers

  • Microservice Trade-Offs

  • Most commonly used git tips and tricks

  • Property-based testing primer

  • React.js Introduction For People Who Know Just Enough jQuery To Get By

  • Saying No to Sales

  • Search Architecture @ Instagram

  • ShipIt by Shopify

  • Small Go Apps Containers

  • Software Engineering Blogs

  • The Art of Monitoring

  • Thoughts and learnings from buliding Strikingly

  • Tuli – A static analysis engine for PHP

  • Up and Running with Docker Machine and OpenStack

  • Using PSR-7 in Symfony

  • Utter Disregard for Git Commit History

  • W3C Push API Crash Course

  • What happens when an Apple guy explores Material Design? — Exploring Material Design

  • Why I use Tape Instead of Mocha

  • cycle-core: A fully reactive JavaScript framework for Human-Computer Interaction

  • google/incremental-dom

  • multi-lingual decentralized p2p chat based on web RTC and Google Translate API

  • ng-model-options: Total Model Control

  • progrium/go-shell

  • MIT comes up with a “no memory” solution for Big Data

  • The 10 Coolest Big Data Products Of 2015 (So Far)

  • Microsoft expands Cortana to power cloud-based predictive analytics

entry.title: Lighting talks #1
entry.content:
On Thursday afternoons the Namshi tech team usually spend some times together, either watching an interesting tech video or having a small retrospective on what’s going on together.

Last Thursday we introduced a new activity: The Namshi Tech Lighting talks. As you probably know, sharing knowledge and experience is very important for us, that’s why we decided to have this new activity where everyone in the team is showing an interesting library/tool.

And we want also to share this with you!

  • Nitesh, one of our frontend developers, showed us a very good way to perform functional test on the UI

http://funcunit.com/

This is a simple and powerful example written by him: http://www.niteshsharma.com/js.metalist/tests/functional/specrunner.html

  • Filippo, from the backend team, talked about a new programming language: Elixir

http://elixir-lang.org/getting-started/introduction.html

  • Amin, from the frontend team, showed us a fancy way of filling empty gaps in the layout:

http://packery.metafizzy.co/

  • Ayham, from the backend team, gave a showcase about some very handy libraries he used in our nodejs projects:

https://github.com/nfriedly/express-rate-limit

https://github.com/medikoo/memoize

  • David, a Symfony lover, talked about new cool stuff on the latest Symfony release, a friendly curl client written in python and a useful git plugin for Sublime editor:

http://symfony.com/blog/new-in-symfony-2-6-vardumper-component

https://github.com/jakubroztocil/httpie#examples

http://www.jisaacks.com/gitgutter#shocked

  • Lucio, went really low level and showed us some tips and tricks to understand what’s going on a network.

http://nmap.org/

https://www.wireshark.org/

  • Hossam, showed us some good tips and advice on how to use promises:

http://taoofcode.net/promise-anti-patterns/

  • Cirpo, shared how tmux and CDPATH can enhance your terminal usage experience:

http://tmux.sourceforge.net/ https://gist.github.com/henrik/1967800

http://linux.101hacks.com/cd-command/cdpath/

  • Shidhin, one of our frontend developers, showed us a nice tool to analyze and optimize your website speed and performance, and he also talked about the easiest way to use git, the regular expressions in JS, and how to run the terminal inside Chrome:

https://github.com/sitespeedio/sitespeed.io

https://github.com/FredrikNoren/ungit

https://github.com/VerbalExpressions/JSVerbalExpressions

https://github.com/petethepig/devtools-terminal

  • Oba, our system admin, showed us an open source system-level tool for analyzing docker containers:

https://github.com/draios/sysdig/wiki/Container-Enabled-Chisels

  • Alex, shared a simple library that allows you to run commands on multiple hosts via SSH, and also he showed how to extend services in docker containers, and how to get your container metrics:

https://github.com/crosbymichael/slex

https://github.com/docker/compose/pull/1088

https://github.com/docker/docker/pull/9984

See you again at the next Namshi Tech Lighting talks!
